wiki:abstract.p: Disraeli (1929) is a film that was adapted by Julien Josephson and De Leon Anthony from a play by Louis N. Parker. The film was directed by Alfred E. Green. It stars George Arliss as British Prime Minister Benjamin Disraeli. His performance won him the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role. The story revolves around the British plan to buy the Suez Canal and the efforts of two spies to stop it.

In 1874, Disraeli's ambitious foreign policy, aiming to create a British empire, is voted down by the House of Commons after a speech by his great rival, William Gladstone. Later, Michael Probert, head of the Bank of England, makes it clear he is vehemently opposed to Disraeli's plans, in particular the purchase of the Suez Canal to secure control of India.

wiki:description.p: When Disraeli receives the welcome news that the spendthrift Khedive of Egypt is in dire need of money and is willing to sell the controlling shares in the canal, he shares the information with Deeford. Then, knowing that he can expect no help from the Bank of England, he summons Hugh Myers, a leading Jewish banker. Foljambe asks Deeford if Myers is there to provide financial backing for the purchase of the canal. Deeford says nothing, but his manner makes it clear that Foljambe has guessed correctly. Mrs. Travers orders Foljambe to leave the country and warn their masters.

Disraeli is elated when he receives the news and makes no attempt to hide it from the prying Mrs. Travers. However, Myers comes and informs him that his banking house has been driven into bankruptcy by Russian sabotage; the check is worthless. Mrs. Travers exults in her key part in bringing about Disraeli's forthcoming disgrace. Thinking quickly, Disraeli summons Probert. Though the banker initially refuses to help, Disraeli forces him to sign a paper giving unlimited credit to Myers by threatening to revoke the bank's charter. (After, Probert leaves, Disraeli confesses to Clarissa and his wife that he has no such power.) As a result of Disraeli's success, Queen Victoria can add Empress of India to her other titles.

wiki:description.p: The Green Goddess was filmed in 1929 and completed before Disraeli, but was held out of release until 1930 at the request of Arliss because he felt this film was a better vehicle for his talkie debut. Silent films titled Disraeli were released in 1916 and 1921, with the 1921 version also starring Arliss.

The film survives in its 1934 re-release form. Originally released with sound on disc, sound on film was added at this later date, resulting in the left side of the image in surviving prints noticeably cropped in order to provide space on which to accommodate the soundtrack. The beginning title cards and screen credits and end title card, however, have been replaced and are therefore centered. Some Pre-Code footage, about three minutes, was also deleted and is believed to be lost.
